key_points: A New Jersey man, Scott V. Spina Jr., was charged with posing as a New England Patriots player to purchase and sell Tom Brady Super Bowl rings.
Spina is facing charges of mail fraud, wire fraud, and aggravated identity theft.
He reportedly bought a Super Bowl LI ring with a bad check from a former Patriots player and sold it for $63,000.
Spina fraudulently ordered three more rings with 'Brady' engraved on them, claiming they were gifts for Tom Brady's nonexistent nephews.
These rings were sold for $100,000, with one later auctioned for $337,219.
Tom Brady did not authorize the creation or distribution of the rings.
Spina pleaded guilty to all five felony charges brought against him.
The buyer began to suspect the authenticity of the rings' backstory due to a discrepancy about Brady's family.
Authorities from the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s Office in the Central District of California are handling the case.
Spina faces up to 92 years in federal prison, though sentencing guidelines may reduce the actual time served.
